data.title: Paul Stephenson – two poems
data.meta_description: Cromer Night There were six people and seven bedrooms, leaving one bedroom for the gales that lashed the town like corporal punishment. The red brick houses, all flats, trembled for the fate of their flimsy sash windows, like rows of yellow guillotines. The sea howled. The pier cracked. Entertainment drowned. There was nowhere to go.…
data.text:
Cromer Night

There were six people

and seven bedrooms,

leaving one bedroom

for the gales that lashed

the town like corporal

punishment. The red brick

houses, all flats, trembled

for the fate of their flimsy

sash windows, like rows

of yellow guillotines.

The sea howled.

The pier cracked.

Entertainment drowned.

There was nowhere to go.

**

Aldeburgh Morning

We should go out now

before the beach has gone haywire

and they’ve lit the town bonfire

and the high street’s rammed with hire cars.

We should put our shoes on and get out

while’s the sun’s still about

and the north end waves are boisterous

and my doubts are sleeping.

We should go outside

while the dishwasher’s dishwashing

and the wind farm on the horizon’s blowing

and the heads of the seals are showing.

We should get out now

and work things through somehow.
